awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrated Field and Laboratory Based Assessment of Liquefaction Triggering and Residual Strength of Gravelly Soil
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the leading causes of damage during earthquakes is soil liquefaction.  Liquefaction causes loose soil to behave more like a heavy liquid than a solid which can result in settlement of buildings as well as landslides and dam failures.  Recently, extensive gravel liquefaction and damage was observed in the 2008 Wenchuan, China, earthquake and the 2014 Cephalonia, Greece, earthquake sequences, and the evidence indicates that gravelly soils that were considered non-liquefiable using existing liquefaction susceptibility methods, did liquefy.  This study will provide a fundamental understanding, as well as practical guidance on assessing whether a gravel deposit will liquefy.  Such deposits are encountered widely and their potential liquefaction is commonly a critical consideration in the stability of our nation's ports, dams, levees and in general, civil infrastructure.  The improved procedures that will be developed will enhance the resiliency of these facilities, and will help in avoiding unnecessary expenses when gravel liquefaction is not really an issue, or more importantly, highlight the need for stabilization when gravel liquefaction is indeed expected.  The research team will establish a web-site with a gravel liquefaction database, and document all available case histories of gravel liquefaction. Videos on the mechanism of liquefaction that can be used for outreach purposes will be developed, as well as a recorded webinar and other educational resources on the outcomes of this study with emphasis on the recommended procedures for liquefaction assessment of gravelly soils. 

Characterization of gravelly soils in a reliable, cost-effective manner for routine engineering projects remains a challenge and methods such as the Cone Penetration Test and Standard Penetration Test are not considered appropriate.  Even for large projects, such as dams and energy projects, characterization is expensive (if Becker testing is used) and problematic. Nevertheless, because liquefaction is known to have occurred in gravelly soils in a significant number of earthquakes, dam engineers are frequently called upon to assess the potential for liquefaction in gravels and liquefaction mitigation costs often run into millions of dollars.  With the majority of research in soil liquefaction engineering focused on the assessment of the likelihood of "triggering" of liquefaction in sands and silty soils, new approaches, and transformative methods for characterizing gravels are needed.  In this collaborative project, there is a coordinated plan that combines unique large scale laboratory testing and innovative field testing at key gravel liquefaction sites to develop liquefaction triggering charts and post-liquefaction shear strength recommendations for gravelly soils.  A prototype 300-mm diameter cyclic simple shear (CSS) device has been developed at the University of Michigan and will be used to evaluate the cyclic (and monotonic) undrained shear response of gravelly soils in the laboratory.  A next-generation dynamic cone penetration test (DPT) that was originally developed in China will be modernized with key instrumentation and will be used for field testing along with in-situ shear wave velocity (Vs) measurements.  Field testing will be conducted in the USA, China, and Greece, leveraging resources from international partners, in-situ testing firms and organizations.  The PIs will leverage well-documented case studies of gravel liquefaction in the recent Cephalonia earthquake to validate the new methods and augment the field performance record of gravel liquefaction.

por.por_cntn:
The response of gravelly soils during earthquake loading is not well understood due to fewer well-documented case histories of field liquefaction as well as the unavailability of large-scale laboratory test devices that can accurately capture material response of large-size particles.

In an effort to address the need for a unified, scalable approach for soil liquefaction deformation analysis a coordinated plan that combines unique large scale laboratory testing and innovative field testing at key gravel liquefaction sites was employed to develop liquefaction triggering charts and post-liquefaction shear strength recommendations for gravelly soils. A prototype 300-mm diameter cyclic simple shear (CSS) device at the University of California, Berkeley was used to evaluate the cyclic (and monotonic) undrained shear response of gravelly soils in the laboratory. A next-generation dynamic cone penetration test (DPT) that was originally developed in China was modernized with key instrumentation and was used for field testing along with in-situ shear wave velocity (Vs) measurements. Shear wave velocity measurements on CSS specimens tested in the laboratory have allowed for the correlation of meso-scale (laboratory) response to the macro scale (field) response. Field testing was conducted in the USA, New Zealand, Greece and China leveraging resources from international partners, in-situ testing firms and organizations. The PIs also leveraged detailed field performance documentation and ongoing field testing of gravel liquefaction of two ports in the 2014 Cephalonia earthquake, as well as the 2016 Kaikoura earthquake to validate the proposed new methods and augment the field performance record of gravel liquefaction. Gravelly deposits are encountered widely and their liquefaction is commonly a critical consideration in the stability of our nation?s ports, dams, levees and in general, civil infrastructure. Overall this work has resulted in improved procedures that enhance the resiliency of these facilities and help avoid unnecessary expenses when gravel liquefaction is not really an issue, or more importantly, highlight the need for stabilization when gravel liquefaction is indeed expected.

Specific major outcomes of this study include:  1) the characterization of the monotonic and cyclic response of uniform and well-graded gravels in terms of monotonic shear strength, liquefaction triggering, post-cyclic shear response (residual strength and reconsolidation volumetric strains) for a wide range of conditions (i.e. density, gradation, vertical load, cyclic stress, and initial shear stress), 2) the development of new DPT and Vs-based probabilistic liquefaction triggering curves specifically for gravelly soils that are based on a heavily expanded database of gravel liquefaction case-histories that represent 137 sites, 10 earthquakes, and 7 countries, 3) the back analysis of two well-documented case-histories of gravel-liquefaction induced lateral spreading at two ports (from the 2014 Cephalonia earthquake in Greece) where our material-specific properties as characterized in our laboratory as well as our new field-testing based triggering procedures were used and tested.

Additional findings include:

Cyclic Simple Shear Response of Gravelly Soils:

-The current ASTM standard for monotonic constant volume testing prescribes a vertical strain during shearing of less than 0.05%. Previous work in our research group showed that this requirement is inadequate and specimens that meet this requirement may have differences in stress-strain response and it was therefore recommended that the threshold is reduced to 0.025% and that the vertical strain during testing is always reported. This was also found to be true for cyclic simple shear testing in this study.

-Cyclic stress ratio vs number of cycles to liquefaction curves have been developed for a range of well graded gravelly soils: it was shown that coefficient of uniformity (Cu), relative density (Dr) and vertical stress affect these curves. Well-graded gravelly soils typically exhibit higher resistance to liquefaction, however they can liquefy even when their initial Vs value is above 200m/s. These CSR curves are particularly important as they are used to calibrate pore-pressure generation models used in numerical modeling of soil liquefaction.

-The presence of initial shear stress prior to cyclic loading can have detrimental effects on the resistance to liquefaction for most gravelly soils, and overall it was shown that the Ka correction factor applied to account for the presence of initial shear stress is overall lower than that applied for sands in similar density/vertical load combinations.

-A new pore pressure generation model for gravels was developed, as well as a model for the assessment of the expected post-cyclic reconsolidation volumetric strain for well-graded gravelly soils.

Field Testing and Characterization of Gravelly Soils:

- Extensive DPT and Vs testing was conducted at a wide range of sites in the USA, New Zealand, Greece and China to expand the gravel liquefaction database, and this testing together with proper geotechnical characterization of these sites allowed for the development of two new gravel-specific liquefaction triggering curves, one based on DPT and one based on Vs. This is the first time that such procedures are available for gravelly soils. A correlation between the DPT and Vs was also developed.
